fields.description: Some are said to be mentally challenged, others like to be. If you are in the latter group, this could be just the thing for you.
I found this in the electrician's department but I don't know what it is intended for.  There's not much electricity in it but you might want to keep a number of other things there.

Did you know why, in sporting events, the home team wears white and the visitors dark colors?  If not, you might need one of these. Actually, one of you has one already.  I forgot I'd gotten one before.
Look! Up in the sky!  It's a bird.  It's a plane. No... it's... it's... Tinker Bell??? Well, she CAN fly. Ages 8 to adult it says. With more adult assistance perhaps you could be younger than that.
Did you think balloons were just for parties? Actually they can be important pieces of scientific apparatus . . . and very educational! Ages 8+ it says.
Twist it. Turn it. Solve it 80 times over. I doesn't spin but you might want to fidget with it anyway.
Ooh! Another science toy! Just up my alley too, though I never thought I had this type of personality. (Ages 8+ it says)
These things can be very useful. I sometimes use mine with my telescope but they would be equally useful if I ever got around to scrubbing the floor.
This handy box comes with a handy book inside, and some rope too. A Boy Scout is not necessary but probably helpful, friendly, courteous and kind.
Everything's up in the air!  But then, with this, it's supposed to be. I can't do this with actual objects. I just have to do it with all the various events of life.
I seem to have an arts and crafts theme woven into this year's collection of gifts. This one uses paper.
Did you ever have to ask yourself "Are those the ones I just took out or are they the ones I was going to put in?" This gift can help you answer that question.
No Alex? No problem! Get these and you can do without him. (Ages 12 and up it says and it may be right about that.)
It says it's for grown-ups but a patient, coordinated, pencil-pushing young person might enjoy this too. It's probably not for the pre-schoolers though.

To boldly match where no one has matched before! Well, I suppose that might have something to do with how to win this game. It says age 7 and up but I think younger ones could play with a little help.
From the days of kings and queens and knights and things comes this familiar pastime.
Stringing along with this year's arts and crafts theme this could help you make anything from a butterfly to a penguin.
Got a bunch of little things that need to be straightened out? This could help you put them in their place.
This is "a quicker picker upper." At least it's quicker than I would be without having a long thin arm.
"Amazing?" they say. "Easy to learn" they say. It might even seem like magic. Not recommended for use in Las Vegas.
Is it on when it should be off? Is if off when it should be on? Try this gift to get things happening at the right time.

Dorothy, trying to connect to herself, has just landed in Oz and opened the door to Walt Disney's Wonderful World.  Yes, I know, her movie was from was MGM. Neither Mickey nor his more recent friends have anything to do with this gift.
This gift might tell you things you didn't know about things you know. Select it to resolve the paradox.
"I can't beam you up, Captain, all major power systems have failed! I can't even see what I'm doing!" Don't let this happen to you. Select this gift.

If you make it normal it goes straight. If you turn it sideways it goes funny. This gift may help you expand your horizons beyond just the two or three designs you already know, but you can still get in trouble if you throw them in class.
Use this to check on your refrigerator or any other flat metallic surface. Unfortunately this check will tell you nothing about your refrigerator.
Did you ever want to know the square root of 86,579? Are you sure you never will? Keep this in your spare "stuff" drawer just to be safe.

"Up periscope!" But you might really want to say "Down periscope," since this item would probably more often be used in that direction. It can help you spy on those pesky little things hiding under other things.

Professor Plum did it in the dining room with the rope. Or was it Miss Scarlet who did it in the kitchen with the knife? Actually this gift has little or nothing to do with a Parker Brothers game but, if you like this sort of thing, it gives you 23 classics, some with which you may already be familiar.

Things don't always happen as they should, such as when I go upstairs to get a book but can't remember why I went up there. Sometimes these moments can happen on a larger scale. Select this gift to see what I mean.

Well, the long and the sort of it is there are fifty of them in here, making this kind of a long gift. But each one of them is short, and they're all American. Select this gift if you want to spend some time with them.

fields.post: I remember Madeline and I, on the day before Christmas, going to the golf course for sledding. I think Pat Gary and maybe the Wiley girls were involved too. We were hoping to make the time go faster.
I remember our first Christmas here. Everything was so pretty with the lights and the snow! My parents drove us around to see all the lights. It was cold but we were still very excited!
I remember examining the Christmas ornaments on Uncle Jim's tree several times throughout the day in the hopes that there was still more candy hidden inside of them.

I received that electric football game that I had been dreaming about. Later that day I was in the bathroom and heard what sounded like the hair clippers. I was so depressed, I thought Dad decided Christmas would be a good day to cut my hair. Instead he had got out the football game, what a relief!
The thing that I remember the most is getting up before the sun to go to Mass.  And no peaking to see if Santa had come.
Baby doll clothes made by Mom in secret.
Cousin Kathy tore my piano music book at Grandpa's

I remember staring out the windows Christmas eve looking for Rudolphs red nose up in the sky. With planes coming and going from the airport we were convinced any red light was Rodolph at the front of Santa's sleigh.
Doing extra chores to earn money to buy Christmas gifts.
The living room, so dark and mysterious as we came down for early mass.  Dad at the kitchen stove,  Mom's coffee cake and a doll I named Pat.
Waiting upstairs on Christmas morning,  waiting to be called down to use bathroom,  and trying to sneak a peek at tree when it was my turn.

One year, when I was stationed at New Buffalo, it was looking like it was going to be a brown Christmas -- no snow anywhere, just dead brown grass.  I remember coming out the front doors of the church after Midnight Mass to the most beautiful white fluffy snowflakes!  It was just like a movie!

fields.question: What commercial from childhood can you say or sing from memory?
If you could bring any cartoon or animated character to life, who would it be and why?
If you could write a letter of gratitude to one of your ancestors, who would you pick and what would you say?
What story do you remember being told from the childhood of your mother or father?
Tell something that you remember about a neighbor from your childhood.
Which celebrity would you want to have as a guest, and what would you get him or her for Christmas?
If you could be a character in a holiday movie, who would you be and why?
Finish this thought, "It wouldn't be Christmas without ______________".  Please exclude the obvious answer.
What was your favorite game to play outside when you were a child?
What was your favorite game to play inside when you were a child?
What "saying" or advice do you remember from your childhood.
What is your favorite Christmas TV program?
When should radio stations start playing Christmas music?
When should Christmas decorations go up?
Real tree or artificial? and why?
What is your earliest childhood Christmas memory?
When you close your eyes and think of your "happy place", where is it
What is your favorite Christmas tradition?
